review_title: Stetson Falls Short in So Many Ways
pros: Small size, fantastic location, plus a world-class faculty adds up to tremendous potential. There are just so many wonderful people here.
cons: Outdated systems and organizational silos combined with oversized egos and questionable ethics in the executive ranks stifle the potential of SU. In spite of having dominion over woefully ineffective campus infrastructure (finance/budgets/accounting, facilities & grounds, technology, human resources) the CFO has way too much control over university priorities and resources. The folks at the top don't play all that well together, and there really aren't any superstars in those ranks. Stetson's leadership hasn't valued professional engagement so faculty and staff (in general) tend not to have high levels of connection, leadership experience and exposure to cutting edge practices. Diversity & Inclusion is a favorite topic - as always - yet things haven't evolved much in the last 25 years, especially where race is concerned.

pros:
The best thing about Stetson are that there are many very good co-workers who are helpful and friendly.  Some senior leadership are great to work for, others... not so much.  The campus is beautiful and well-kept.  The students are fun if you have the opportunity to get to know them.  They want to know that you care about them.  

Tuition waiver makes it worth the lower salaries for staff, but that only is valid for the staff taking advantage of the tuition waiver.
cons:
Some senior leadership are very cliquish and they don’t like you, then forget it.  

The differences between divisions can be huge. Some divisions are laid back and without much funding for staff events such as professional development or retreats, while other divisions have a lot of “fun” money for numerous retreats and conferences a year along with food and swag galore.  Staff notice the difference.  What is the deal?  

There also isn’t much room for advancement for staff.  Some departments only have one employee.

job_title: Assistant Director of Education Services in Deland, FL
pros:
Tuition benefits
Warm culture
Emphasis on inclusivity
cons:
lower-than-average salary and pay
departmental management can be drastically different from one area to another

job_title: Student Lab Assistant in Deland, FL
pros: Good environment and everyone is super supportive
cons: Not much growth opportunities and it can be a bit boring since the school is quite small.

pros: I have learned a lot in my position and this has been a great way for me to become acclimated to working in a professional environment without taking a full-time position. The tuition benefit is the only reason to stay in one of these positions.
cons: The pay is atrocious. The GA package underwent a pay scale change recently and is definitely improved, but not substantially better. Many of the GA positions on campus are inflexible in  their scheduling: we have one week of vacation to be used in the summer. There is no time to visit friends or family in the fall or spring unless campus is closed.  Many GA's report being treated as if they were full time faculty, being given projects and responsibilities that are far beyond their pay scale. It is a delicate balance between a GA position and being a grad student, especially when it's the end of the semester and your office is slammed and you have finals, but you can't take off any time from work because you're mandated to fill 20-25 hours per week.  A lot of this boils down to what department you're in-- pay close attention to who your bosses' boss will be/is. That should clue you in.

review_title: Nice school but very low pay
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Deland, FL
pros: Great school, nice staff and faculty.
cons: Low pay, not a lot of diversity within the staff

pros: Flexibility, not difficult, opportunity to learn professional skills
cons: Can be boring, not great pay.

review_title: Administrative Assistant at Law School Campus
pros: I was fortunate to work in a "friendly" office on the campus.  Again, I  worked at the Law School campus in Gulfport, FL.  The campus was beautiful, the other employees were very nice for the most part, and the overall experience was very relaxed.  Wonderful work-life balance (as long as you don't abuse it).  I didn't have any benefits so I can't comment on that, but I heard from other employees that they were alright.  There were also nice banquets and celebrations for staff appreciation.  I would probably still be with Stetson if I didn't have to move too far to commute.
cons: The version of the database we used, BANNER, was horrible.  It was the very basic edition, very hard to navigate, and not user friendly at all.  The school is very adverse to change whether it be technological or HR related.  The students and professors had amazing and current technology,but the staff were left in the Dark Ages.  Also, not very much room for advancement.  Many staff members had been with the school for a very very long time and there was rarely any promotions unless someone retired or died.

pros: small community, nice people, nice campus
cons: lacks diversity, low pay, low opportunity

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Washington, DC
pros: Good pay just show me info
cons: Racist and Expensive this is stupid

review_title: Great work-life balance, friendly work environment and College is striving for further success.
job_title: Assistant Director of Academic Success and Bar Preparation Services in Gulfport, FL
pros: Hire solid individuals; thus, it is a joy to go to work each day and work among a friendly, intellectual and hard-working group.  The College of Law strives to get better each year; therefore, they challenge each department on campus to reach a high bar.  I work closely with a team of four other people in my department who are dedicated to the students and bringing value to the College of Law.  Opportunity to build great relationships with students who are very appreciative of your assistance with their academics and passing the bar exam.  Work-life balance is easily achieved as it is generally a 8:30-5pm job which generally brings little stress.
cons: The salary is $16,000 less than the average pay for this type of position and the College of Law is currently not in a position to increase our salaries due to decreased enrollment and such.  The work isn't very challenging...once you learn how to perform this job (which takes only a couple of months) it gets a bit redundant.  I am an attorney and thus I wouldn't mind more intellectual stimulation throughout the day.

review_title: A good place to work in a sunny, laid-back small Florida town
pros:
My colleagues were smart and devoted to their teaching and administrative work.
Stetson is located in DeLand, walking distance from a small but charming downtown with lots of independent businesses.  
It's very pleasantly sunny and warm in the depths of winter.
I worked at Stetson from 2008 to 2012 (it says 2015 above only because I wasn't allowed to give an earlier date), and the campus got more physically attractive when President Libby came on board, and has apparently expanded and gotten more attractive since.
cons: When I worked there, pay for faculty was lower than at peer universities.

review_title: Doing its best but not enough
job_title: Office Administrator in Lake Mary, FL
pros: Positive culture, passionate folks who want students to succeed
cons: Bad pay, incredibly stressful, very surface level when it comes to diversity stuff

review_title: Lowest pay in area, high staff turnover
pros: The new landscaping of the Stetson DeLand Campus is beautiful and maintained well. The faculty is dedicated and knowledgeable. Parking is ample.
cons: Salary is lowest in the region; staff overworked causing constant turnover whether staff is inexperienced or experienced; not uncommon for employees to be asked to work far beyond the contracted hours if salaried; not uncommon for the same postion to be vacated and filled every 15 months; unrealistic workloads unrelated to job description are dumped on staff at the last minute due to disorganized upper administration;job responsibilities incongruent with job titles thus allowing for such low pay with ever increasing responsibilities; lots of dissension between upper administration, faculty & staff due to continually increasing responsibilities resulting in constant in-fighting and a stressful work environment; poor support structure for staff and faculty; insurance benefits for families are more expensive than other colleges and universities; Work life balance is not valued or supported.

pros: Educational atmosphere and environment; not as fast paced as a commercial job.
cons: Those who are not "academic" (ie: faculty) are second class employees. Stetson is struggling with revenues and retention.  Raises are poor and do not keep up with the cost of living much less provide any merit increases.  Facilities and equipment needs suffer.  There is an unhealthy obsession with sports, and since dogs are permitted on campus, there is a flea problem in the common areas.  Very little opportunity for growth and promotion.

review_title: Look beyond the idyllic campus view
pros: If you love helping students, Stetson is a good place to work. If you like a beautiful campus, Stetson may work for you.
cons: No opportunities for personal growth, recognition or advancement. Loyal, competent and hardworking employees are all but exploited until burnout or until competitive infighting takes over their priority. Competitive infighting comes down from the top, and middle management is the most oppressive. Small town, job scarcity and fear-based incentive to continue working in a toxic environment.

review_title: Good place to work if you're looking for a stepping stone in your career.
pros: Time-off is generous compared to other companies. The campus is beautiful and the location is within walking distance to many downtown restaurants.
cons: Expect to be paid at least 20% less than what an average salary in Florida is for a comparable position. Cost of health insurance and dental plan is expensive. I opted to just pay cash at the dentist because it was more affordable than a plan. The areas surrounding the campus are undesirable and extra precautions should be taken for personal safety when off campus. The staff employment has a high turn-over rate. Technology and business practices are outdated. A lot of departments operate like it is still the 90's. If you're not at the top of the food chain, don't expect to be a valued employee.

pros: Stetson is an amazing place to work, if you are up for the challenge. There is a lot of work to be done, and a lot of people who have high expectations of you. There is also a great deal of opportunity to grow as a person and as a professional. My experience was one of coming into a fairly new position and having the capacity to make it my own, which I've realized is very rare. The leadership is incredibly supportive, and professional development is not just something that is talked about, but actively planned and reflected upon. I loved my time at Stetson and I will always be appreciative of the opportunity to start my career there.
cons: Low salaries, which leads to turnover.

review_title: Opportunity to Enhance Your Skills and Get Paid
job_title: Student Worker-Digital Arts Lab Assistant in Deland, FL
pros:
Allows you to grow in your skill set with programs on Stetson's Digital Art computers (Macs)
Hours are flexible
Working on Campus
Supervisors respond efficiently
May be able to perform other duties along with helping students and monitoring the lab, like checking out video and audio equipment--Dr. Wolek let me do so after monitoring the lab for two years
cons:
Shifts before or after yours may not be covered, but you can be paid for covering shifts
Less and less students came to the lab each year--either working in the 24-hour Flagler Lab instead or purchasing their own equipment to use
The Davis building is far away from many of the dorms-long walking distance for someone with physical limitations, but can be compensated with transport from Public Safety

review_title: Lots of bureaucracy, but isn't that true everywhere?
pros: As much as I would like to say my time at Stetson has been bad, truthfully, I really don't think it's worse than any other place. Work is work, only for a few lucky people do they truly get to enjoy it. The coworkers are nice, and there is a strong sense of community.
cons: Long hours, low pay. That's pretty typical for non-profits though. I'd like to find gripe about specifics, trust me, but truthfully it isn't worse than any other place.

pros: As others have said, the campus is beautiful. There are several programs employees can take advantage of and a good fitness center and classes. Tuition reimbursement (you can't beat that) and great academic programs.  People there are generally friendly.
cons: It's true what others have said about alumni. There are MANY working there. In some cases, that's good: they love the place and are devoted to it; in other cases, it's bad: they feel ENTITLED; they seem to move up the ranks even when performance is poor; and they get away with treating others poorly.

review_title: They have lost all companionship for any employees
pros: Stetson University is a good secure  Job a fair place to work they do not pay very well they have benefits  but over the years those have seem to diminish as well but you can continue to work there it is very hard to be fired
cons: Several years back they were a good company to work for but as the time has passed between the years of 2000 to 2015 things have slowly diminished and now they are just for making money and not worrying about the little guy that works for them

review_title: Lots of good things about this place; pay for staff is very low.
pros: I worked under both previous management and current management. The changes being made by current management and those that have been made already (in terms of administration - can't comment on the faculty side) have been positive and seem strategic/long term. Friendly, kind people in general; beautiful campus; great working conditions; positive attitudes; great location; easy parking for staff; lots of wonderful funder relationships (in development); good place to launch a career; free tuition (the only way the salary is worth it); genuinely good people to work with; excellent reputation among funders (in general); in fundraising, good systems and standards; good opportunities for collaboration with faculty; faculty are top-notch and generally great to work with from staff perspective (not always true at colleges); education is excellent if you use tuition benefit; retirement plan (at least when I was there) was quite good; generally, workload is manageable (I've worked at non-profits that are substantially more demanding...in a bad way).
cons: Terribly low salaries when I was there (like, below the 10th percentile on national scale), without much promise for improvement; limited understanding of how to motivate employees or even keep them on board; relatively high turnover rates except among those who won't leave no matter what (if you know what I mean); limited diversity (heavy on the white women demographic); in the department I was in, very (VERY) little flexibility in schedule (read: no workshifting whatsoever; as salaried employee, must mark on timesheet if you leave an hour early for a doctor's appointment; lots of clockwatching; complaints if you are in the office more than 7 minutes late--I've found that this is a very unusual approach in fundraising). The people are generally wonderful, but I also had one of the worst run-ins with middle management I've ever had with anyone (and it was extremely unwarranted and, frankly, very strange!).

pros: Beautiful environment and care of facilities, like a transplanted ivy league institution, in some ways. Very strong core faculty, traditions.
cons: While enrollment and investment in infrastructure has risen, the changes are at a significant cost: less personal attention, more adjunct teachers, larger class size, more effort to increasing growth through the newly reinstituted football program. Basically, it's becoming more like a regular undergraduate school.

job_title: Intramural Sports Supervisor in Boynton Beach, FL
pros: Excellent training that helps supervisors become comfortable with their work environment and prepares them for any and all job responsibilities.  This is more than just a work/study job at Stetson University because this job has real responsibilities and will force the person in it to grow and develop important skills for the working world.
cons: Working for the intramural department can be unorganized sometimes because it is dependent on player participation, weather, ect.  This means that sometimes you will show up for a shift for it to be cancelled / delayed due to lack of players or unplayable weather conditions.

pros: Excellent potential for advancement, provided you fit the bourgeois and elitist aesthetic the college hopes to achieve.
cons: Pay is not commiserate with that of other institutions.   Supervisors tend to treat employees as though there is some large experiential or educational gap between the two, when often the employees are more educated than their superiors.

pros: Stetson has a great work environment and beautiful campuses. Feels like excellence is expected but without the ivory tower attitude. I had wonderful colleagues who wanted to see me succeed. I worked with master's students, and the were motivated. Many of them had such a great undergraduate experience that they only wanted to continue their masters work at Stetson.
cons: Poor pay for adjunct professors. No benefits.

review_title: Great place to earn some extra cash as a student, and get valuable experience at the same time
job_title: Math Clinic Tutor in Deland, FL
pros: I enjoyed working with other students.  It helped me to reinforce math concepts I had previously learned.
cons: Some students are difficult to explain things too, and they can get frustrated or impatient if you don't just tell them the answer.  But I think that is valuable experience for the workplace (learning how to deal with people).

review_title: Good place to get started as a career
pros: Good benefits. Hard work through recruiting cycle. Slow summers provide flexible time off.
cons: Results driven, so don't plan on any time off if your territory isn't very strong for the university. Pay is kinda low across the board for the profession, but Stetson is right at the average. The city of Deland may leave young professionals with a little more to be desired.

pros: historic campus; aesthetic beauty; close to downtown shops and restaurants
cons:
Stetson reminds me of a theatrical performance; it's a polished show on the front (public view), but absolute chaos backstage/behind the curtain (office operations). 

If you're not a major donor or alumni member, you are viewed as and treated like a second-class employee. If you're not part of the "in" crowd, you will be publicly shunned and excluded. If your supervisor is an alumni (which they likely will be), understand that they will be in that job for life, regardless of how inept and clueless they may be. 

Stetson is very management-heavy. In some departments, there are managers for only one employee! 

There is no integrity or accountability at Stetson. Preference/special treatment is afforded to the closest friends of management. If - for whatever reason - you're not lucky enough to get on the "list," you'll be out of there as soon as management can find an alumni applicant to take your place. 

Stetson is very much a "good ol' boys" network. Think high school clique: same foolish games, only the people are now 20+ years older, with graduate degrees.  
 
The culture is crass and there is no employer courtesy or respect. In most areas, there is no room for advancement, promotion, or raise. Original ideas are either immediately squashed, or manipulated to appear as the idea of someone else - usually an alumni or favored employee.  

Professional development and continuing education is frowned upon. Collaboration and communication with co-workers outside your department is discouraged. It's like working for a jealous girlfriend. You are constantly being watched, monitored, and micro-manged.   

In the end, this is a very restrictive place to work. If you enjoy being a mindless drone - accepting barked orders from clueless and inept "leaders" - Stetson will be a great fit. Otherwise, enjoy the aesthetic landscaping and architecture, but steer cleer of working for this vindicive and out-of-touch employer.

review_title: Student should be the main focus
pros: Stetson is great because it is a small school and it is easy to communicate to professors or get help with anything.
cons: I feel like students arent the main focus but making money. The school gets bigger student wise but the campus doesn't change so places are packed. The food really sucks.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Employment by the law campus still carries some prestige on the resume but not for long... the main campus is quickly ruining any remaining respectability the law school has earned through the years.
cons: It appears Deland is pillaging the law school for the money and leaving little behind. The buildings are moldy and in disrepair. Staff with JDs are treated like hourly employees and get paid less than public defenders and good paralegals. On top of the meager salary, must pay for own insurance and benefits. Hourly employees are treated even worse. Once in the door, you are expected to be grateful for a 1% salary increase each year. Only professors get paid a living wage and appear not to care that the place is in a downward spiral.  NO ONE gets promoted except for maybe a very modest upgrade from "asst director" to "associate director." Summer classes are almost non existent, and students are commenting on the lack of resources and declining campus. Upholstery on chairs throughout campus are ripped open. Incompetent people remain in charge of departments in spite of doing nothing all day, every day. This decline has been in place since the current president was hired in Deland, who is thankfully leaving - yet there is no reason to believe someone of equal caliber & mindset would be chosen as her replacement. The law school is being "rebranded" with the undergrad mascot of a cartoon hat...one can only assume this is being dictated also from Deland. It is a shame what is taking place. Being a Stetson attorney used to mean something.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Deland, FL
pros: Pretty campus, higher salaries if you work in the business school or admin for a comparatively low cost of living. Faculty are really nice.
cons: Bloated and incompetent administration that is not transparent and micro-manages, mission-drift, borderline illiterate and hostile student body, intransigent or sometimes outwardly hostile toward faculty needs, ever expanding job descriptions without corresponding increases in pay.

pros: I worked as a Resident Assistant, and you get free housing for the year plus $1000 over the course of the year. Your Residential Life Coordinator (RLC) cares about you
cons: At times, can be hard to manage work alongside academics. Organizing too many programs can be difficult and if you are duty on holidays, that can be bit upsetting

review_title: This is a great place to work, but it's common to be stuck in your position.
pros: Great environment, lots of employee perks around holidays, employee appreciation, friendly people, beautiful facility.
cons: You will be stuck in the position you're hired for, there is barely any upward movement, there is no room for change

pros: If you have the right political backing, you can accomplish some amazing things
cons: If you have the wrong political entities that don't like you, your life will be made miserable; it's an extremely dysfunctional place, that doesn't like to talk about elephants under rugs, with people who conveniently forget what they say.

review_title: Most rewarding employment I have ever had!
job_title: Supervisor for Special Projects (Construction, Renovation) in Deland, FL
pros:
Challenging work environment, excellent support from all level of management and academic support.
Compensation commensurate with experience and abilities.
cons: None that I experienced with a 9 plus year history of working at Stetson.

pros: Great momentum. A lot of vibrancy around improvements in quality and expansion and modernizing old sytems
cons: Location limits talent pool and institution needs to acknowledge it will take greater effort to find talent. Old guard not allowing this.

review_title: Small school that could be great
job_title: Assistant Director of Facilities and Operations in Deland, FL
pros: Getting younger people in with fresh ideas
cons: Not enough staffing, lose good staffing quickly because they are over worked and under compensated.  Quality of life is not a positive for anyone not an upper administrator.

pros: Easy to travel to work if you live on campus. Relatively easy work and flexible on hours due to the courses you will be taking each semester.
cons: The pay for students is just above minimum wage.

review_title: Stetson is overdue for a change in leadership.
pros: The students and colleagues are great.
cons: Poor compensation and an absence of effective leadership.

pros: Flexible hours, tons of different work opportunities and good learning experiences.
cons: Not all job opportunities are good and some of the department managers are terrible.

pros: Helpful and understanding professional staff, great work environment for students to learn professional skills
cons: Overall professional staff was great but certain areas within the department lacked accountability for their student employees

pros: Great People, Flexible schedule, boss always willing to help
cons: Students want you to do their work for them and they are usually unprepared

review_title: Positive environment, but shallow relationship with employees.

cons: No parking. No care for employees from the executive level. Employees viewed as replaceable.

pros: Small campus, small classroom sizes, mostly dedicated students
cons: Ridiculous workload, unethical practices not addressed, minimal faculty support

pros: Flexible hours and easy to talk to
cons: Very busy and work way more hours than logged.

Manager is very helpful and understanding

Pay is alright
